data.introduction: If you're looking to impress your family and friends this holiday season or simply want to master the art of cooking a succulent turkey, this simple roast turkey recipe is your go-to guide. With a perfectly seasoned 12-14 lb whole turkey, infused with fresh herbs and roasted to golden-brown perfection, your dinner table will become the centerpiece of joy and gratitude. This recipe not only highlights a blend of classic flavors—think rosemary, thyme, and garlic—but also ensures that your turkey remains juicy and tender thanks to a thoughtful basting technique and a splash of chicken broth. Whether you're a seasoned chef or a novice in the kitchen, follow our step-by-step instructions to create a mouthwatering roast turkey that will make your holiday gatherings memorable. Prepare to carve into a feast that everyone will rave about!
data.SEOTitle: Simple Roast Turkey Recipe: Perfect for Holiday Gatherings
data.SEODescription: Discover how to make a simple roast turkey that is juicy and flavorful with our easy-to-follow recipe. Perfect for Thanksgiving or any festive gathering!

cookingSteps.name: Preheat the Oven
cookingSteps.description: Set your oven to 325°F (165°C) to ensure it reaches the right temperature for roasting your turkey.

cookingSteps.name: Prepare the Turkey
cookingSteps.description: Remove the giblets from the turkey's cavity. Pat the turkey dry thoroughly with paper towels to ensure crispy skin during roasting.

cookingSteps.name: Season the Turkey
cookingSteps.description: Rub the turkey generously inside and out with salt (1/4 cup) and black pepper (2 tsp). This step is crucial for flavor.

cookingSteps.name: Add Olive Oil
cookingSteps.description: Drizzle 1/4 cup of olive oil over the turkey and rub it in evenly. This will help to brown the skin and keep the meat moist.

cookingSteps.name: Stuff the Cavity
cookingSteps.description: Fill the cavity of the turkey with quartered onion, chopped carrots, chopped celery, minced garlic, and fresh herbs (2 tbsp each of rosemary and thyme). This adds flavor from the inside out.

cookingSteps.name: Position the Turkey
cookingSteps.description: Place the turkey breast-side up on a rack in a roasting pan. The rack allows air to circulate around the turkey for even cooking.

cookingSteps.name: Add Chicken Broth
cookingSteps.description: Pour 4 cups of chicken broth into the bottom of the roasting pan. This will create steam during cooking, keeping the turkey moist.

cookingSteps.name: Roast the Turkey
cookingSteps.description: Roast your turkey in the preheated oven. Baste it every 30 minutes with the drippings from the pan. Cook until the internal temperature reaches 165°F (74°C) in the thickest part of the thigh, which usually takes about 3 to 4 hours.

cookingSteps.name: Rest the Turkey
cookingSteps.description: Once cooked, remove the turkey from the oven and allow it to rest for at least 20 minutes before carving. This helps the juices redistribute, resulting in a moister turkey.

pairings.pairings: Serve the roast turkey with classic accompaniments such as homemade cranberry sauce, buttery mashed potatoes, and a rich gravy made from the pan drippings. For beverages, pair with a crisp white wine like Sauvignon Blanc or a light-bodied red such as Pinot Noir. A refreshing apple cider or sparkling water with lemon can be a delightful non-alcoholic option.
pairings.serving_suggestions: Present the turkey on a large platter, garnished with fresh herbs like rosemary and thyme for visual appeal. Serve alongside a colorful array of roasted seasonal vegetables such as Brussels sprouts and sweet potatoes to complement the flavors of the turkey. For a festive touch, consider adding decorative elements like fresh cranberries or orange slices around the turkey.
pairings.dietary_considerations: This roast turkey recipe is naturally gluten-free and can be made dairy-free by avoiding any butter in the sides. For those looking for a low-sodium option, reduce the amount of salt used and opt for low-sodium chicken broth. Additionally, the turkey can be paired with a variety of stuffing options, including gluten-free bread or vegetable-based stuffing for those with dietary restrictions.

faqs.question: How do I prepare a whole turkey before cooking it?
faqs.answer: Start by removing the giblets from the cavity, then pat the turkey dry with paper towels. This helps achieve a crispy skin. Rub salt and black pepper both inside and outside the turkey.

faqs.question: What is the best way to season the turkey?
faqs.answer: Use a mix of salt, black pepper, olive oil, and fresh herbs like rosemary and thyme. Drizzle olive oil over the turkey and rub it in for added flavor and moisture.

faqs.question: How do I know the turkey is fully cooked?
faqs.answer: The internal temperature should reach 165°F (74°C) in the thickest part of the thigh. Use a meat thermometer for accuracy.

faqs.question: How often should I baste the turkey?
faqs.answer: Baste the turkey every 30 minutes. This adds moisture and flavor to the meat, helping to keep it juicy.

faqs.question: What should I do if the turkey skin is browning too quickly?
faqs.answer: If the skin is browning too fast, cover the turkey loosely with aluminum foil to prevent burning while the inside finishes cooking.

faqs.question: How long do I need to let the turkey rest after cooking?
faqs.answer: Let the turkey rest for at least 20 minutes before carving. This allows the juices to redistribute, keeping the meat moist.

faqs.question: What kind of pan should I use to roast a turkey?
faqs.answer: Use a roasting pan with a rack to allow air circulation around the turkey. This helps it cook evenly and achieve that golden brown skin.

faqs.question: Can I cook the turkey without stuffing it?
faqs.answer: Absolutely! Cooking the turkey unstuffed is common. Just season it well and use broth in the roasting pan to keep it moist.

faqs.question: What do I do with the leftovers?
faqs.answer: Store leftovers in airtight containers in the refrigerator for up to 3-4 days. You can use them in sandwiches, soups, or casseroles.

faqs.question: Is it safe to thaw a frozen turkey?
faqs.answer: Yes, but make sure to thaw it in the refrigerator, in cold water, or in the microwave—never at room temperature. Plan for about 24 hours of thawing for every 4-5 pounds.

ingredients.name: whole turkey
ingredients.advice: When choosing a turkey, look for one that is fresh and has a good amount of fat beneath the skin for moisture. If you can’t find a whole turkey, a bone-in turkey breast can be a good substitute, but adjust cooking times accordingly. Be sure to thaw frozen turkey in the fridge for several days before cooking.

ingredients.name: salt
ingredients.advice: Use kosher salt for a more even distribution and better flavor absorption. If using table salt, reduce the amount slightly as it is denser. Consider brining the turkey in a saltwater solution for a few hours or overnight for added moisture.

ingredients.name: black pepper
ingredients.advice: Freshly cracked black pepper has a stronger flavor than pre-ground pepper, so use a grinder if possible. For a different flavor profile, try incorporating white pepper or even smoked paprika for a slight kick.

ingredients.name: olive oil
ingredients.advice: Extra virgin olive oil will enhance the flavor of the turkey, but you can substitute with melted butter for a richer taste. If you’re looking for a healthier option, use a light olive oil.

ingredients.name: fresh rosemary
ingredients.advice: Fresh rosemary adds a fragrant, woodsy flavor. If you don’t have fresh, you can use 1 teaspoon of dried rosemary, but reduce the quantity as dried herbs are more potent. Alternatively, thyme can be used as a substitute.

ingredients.name: fresh thyme
ingredients.advice: Thyme pairs well with turkey and can be substituted with sage for a slightly different flavor. If using dried thyme, reduce the amount to about 1 teaspoon.

ingredients.name: garlic cloves, minced
ingredients.advice: Use fresh garlic for the best flavor. If you find yourself without fresh garlic, 1/8 teaspoon of garlic powder can be a substitute, but will not have the same punch.

ingredients.name: onion, quartered
ingredients.advice: Onions add sweetness and depth to the turkey. You can substitute with shallots for a milder flavor, or use another aromatic like leeks.

ingredients.name: carrots, chopped
ingredients.advice: Carrots add sweetness and color. If you’re out of carrots, parsnips can be a good substitute. For a twist, consider adding some sweet potatoes for additional flavor.

ingredients.name: celery stalks, chopped
ingredients.advice: Celery adds a subtle crunch and flavor. If you don’t have celery, you can substitute with fennel for a slightly different taste or omit it altogether.

ingredients.name: chicken broth
ingredients.advice: Use low-sodium chicken broth to control the salt content. If you prefer a vegetarian option, vegetable broth will work, but keep in mind the flavor might be less rich.

mealId.name: Simple Roast Turkey
mealId.quickTastyDescription: A classic roast turkey that's juicy, flavorful, and perfect for any occasion.
detailedCookingInstructions: Remove the turkey giblets and pat the turkey dry with paper towels.
Rub the turkey inside and out with salt and black pepper.
Drizzle olive oil over the turkey and rub it in evenly.
Stuff the cavity with quartered onion, chopped carrots, chopped celery, minced garlic, and herbs.
Place the turkey breast-side up on a rack in a roasting pan.
Add chicken broth to the bottom of the pan to keep the turkey moist during cooking.
Roast the turkey in the preheated oven, basting every 30 minutes, until the internal temperature reaches 165°F (74°C) in the thickest part of the thigh, about 3 to 4 hours.
Let the turkey rest for at least 20 minutes before carving.
